title: Galway West General Election 2024 updates : Noel Grealish takes fifth and last seat
body_text:
Galway West General Election 2024 updates: Noel Grealish takes fifth and last seat
Mairéad Farrell (SF), Catherine Connolly (Ind), John Connolly (FF), Hildegarde Naughton (FG) and Noel Grealish (Ind) are electedSenator Seán Kyne has announced his retirement from politicsGráinne Seoige commented on running her first election campaign, on the ‘celebrity tag’ and on the criticism over the cancer care ad
No of seats: 5
Seats filled: 5
And that’s a wrap! The new Galway West TDs are: Mairéad Farrell (SF), Catherine Connolly (Ind), John Connolly (FF) and Hildegarde Naughton (FG) and Noel Grealish (Ind)
3.20am – Count 16 results: Noel Grealish takes the last seat in Galway West!
Noel Grealish 9,649
Noel Thomas 8,749
2.20am – Count 15 results: John Connolly's surplus votes have been redistributed but nobody reached the quota to be elected. Noel Grealish is now 659 votes ahead of Noel Thomas. Now, Hildegarde Naughton’s surplus votes will be redistributed. The next count is expected to be the last one for Galway West!
Noel Grealish 9,081
Noel Thomas 8,422
2am – Many are now leaving the count centre and I am finishing today’s snacks. However, there is still one seat in Galway West to be filled and Irish Independent reporters like myself stay until the end, like heroes. We await for count 15.
Noel Grealish 8,717
Noel Thomas 8,134
1.20am – Count 14 results: Cllr John Connolly and TD Hildegarde Naughton have been elected. John Connolly's surplus votes will be distributed for the last seat to be filled. Noel Grealish is currently 583 votes ahead of Noel Thomas.
John Connolly 10,988
Noel Grealish 8,717
Hildegarde Naughton 10,942
Noel Thomas 8,134
00.30am – We are still waiting for the results of count 14 here at Galway City's Lawn Tennis Club. In the meantime, Senator Seán Kyne has announced his retirement from politics following his elimination from the race.
“I think I have been retired by the electors,” he told the media this evening.
Senator Kyne explained he doesn’t want to put his family through another election campaign but, after 20 years in politics, he does not know what he is going to do next.
11.30pm – Count 13 results: Seán Kyne has been eliminated and his votes will now be redistributed. It’s a tight race between Hildegarde Naughton and Noel Thomas.
John Connolly 9,746
Noel Grealish 8,222
Seán Kyne 6,371
Hildegarde Naughton 7644
Noel Thomas 7242
10.10pm – Count 12 results: Nobody was elected or eliminated. Catherine Connolly surplus votes will now be redistributed.
John Connolly 9,592
Noel Grealish 8,148
Seán Kyne 6,281
Hildegarde Naughton 7,474
Noel Thomas 7,199
8.45pm – Count 11 results: Sinn Féin Mairéad Farrell and independent Catherine Connolly have both been re-elected! They are the first two candidates to be elected at Galway West this weekend. Farrell’s surplus votes will now be redistributed.
John Connolly 9484
Catherine Connolly 10,578
Mairead Farrell 10,610
Noel Grealish 8,079
Seán Kyne 6,235
Hildegarde Naughton 7,395
Noel Thomas 7,138
Read more
7pm – Count 10 results: Sinn Féin Mairéad Farrell and Fianna Fáil John Connolly are now neck and neck for the first seat of Galway West.
John Connolly jumped to 9,291 votes after receiving 1,437 transfer votes from running partner Gráinne Seoige.
Eibhlín Seoighthe has been eliminated and her votes will now be redistributed.
John Connolly 9291
Catherine Connolly 8977
Mairead Farrell 9532
Noel Grealish 7969
Seán Kyne 6042
Hildegarde Naughton 7082
Eibhlín Seoighthe 3911
Noel Thomas 7017
6pm – As Galway West awaits for the count 10 to be announced, it is getting clearer and clearer who are at the end of their race.
Among them, Social Democrats candidate Eibhlín Seoighthe – who so far received 3,841 votes – said that, despite a boost of over 800 transfer votes from Labour candidate Helen Ogbu, she is aware she will not get a seat at the Dáil this time.
Ms Seoighthe told the Irish Independent she is feeling “good and proud” of this year’s result.
"I know I’m not going to take a seat but with a campaign that was only three weeks long I was actually really impressed with the outcome, really impressed with my team that have been supporting me through it and really grateful to the constituency that chose to give me so many votes, I am really blown away. So feeling good and proud.”
As many have already left the count centre, Ms Seoighthe explained why she decided to stay until the end.
"I take great pride on the work and I want to be here for the party, I want to be here for the supporters that are here, they deserve to see me still here and still standing.”
She added she intends to put her name forward once again at the next general election: “The plan is to keep on going and to keep on working away and see how we can grow and develop from here.”
5.30pm – Count 9 results: Fianna Fáil’s Gráinne Seoige has been officially eliminated while Mairead Farrell is still far away from the quota. Social Democrats’ Eibhlín Seoighthe has received 886 transfer votes from Labour candidate Helen Ogbu.
John Connolly 7854
Catherine Connolly 8750
Mairead Farrell 9335
Noel Grealish 7777
Seán Kyne 5727
Hildegarde Naughton 6741
Gráinne Seoige 3162
Eibhlín Seoighthe 3841
Noel Thomas 6736
4.10pm – Count 8 results: Labour Party Helen Ogbu has been eliminated as we are still waiting for the first seat to be filled.
John Connolly 7694
Catherine Connolly 8150
Mairead Farrell 9093
Noel Grealish 7702
Seán Kyne 5600
Hildegarde Naughton 6473
Helen Ogbu 2622
Gráinne Seoige 3082
Eibhlín Seoighthe 2955
Noel Thomas 6673
3.40pm – Mike Cubbard said he will keep working in politics as he is both proud of his campaign and disappointed he was eliminated. Cllr Cubbard was eliminated at the seventh count with 2,451 votes.
“I’m disappointed overall, because I think I would have brought something to the table in Dublin for Galway. But Galway wants and needs a strong independent voice and we have that in Deputy Connolly and Deputy Grealish now.
“Obviously I’m disappointed, I’m tired, I’ll reflect with my family and my supporters in the next couple of days. But I have a very small team, I have a team of five - six people, and to get over 2,400 votes, I’m quite proud of it.”
Commenting on his campaign, Cllr Cubbard added: “The general election is quite different to the local election, where you can see the vast difference in big teams and big budgets that the big parties would have at the general election. You’re up against the big machine as a small independent.
“It was a very short campaign, very different, I like to knock on doors and meet people, speak to people, we didn’t get to do that this time.
“The weather was poor, the snow, the red warning. I was away for a couple of days as well, I had committed to take 45 kids from a football club in the city to Agadir, in Morocco. I wasn’t going to break a promise to the kids.
“It wasn’t ideal but I’m proud of that campaign.”
He added about the future: “I’m very proud to be a councillor, I’m very proud I topped the poll back in June, I’m 39 years of age, I’m not going anywhere soon, I keep building.”
2.45pm – Count 7 results: nobody is elected as Mairead Farrell is still far away from the quota of 10,047. Independent candidate Mike Cubbard has now been eliminated and his votes will be redistributed.
John Connolly 7457
Catherine Connolly 7554
Mike Cubbard 2451
Mairead Farrell 8654
Noel Grealish 7265
Seán Kyne 5522
Hildegarde Naughton 6353
Helen Ogbu 2514
Gráinne Seoige 3016
Eibhlín Seoighthe 2885
Noel Thomas 6463
2pm – Briefly talking with the media, Ms Seoige said she is disappointed with the result, but happy she ran an “honest and spirited” campaign.
“I’m really proud of the campaign that we ran, I’m really humbled by the amount people who took part in my campaign and wanted to be there for me. I’m really delighted with the friends I’ve made on the way because I met people and I got to know people that believed in me, and supported me and we actually had a lot of craic in this campaign, a lot of moments that I’m gonna treasure.
“I’m disappointed it didn’t work out, but I’m very proud that I took the opportunity and made the journey. Nobody achieves anything in this life unless they leave their comfort zone, and I did that, and that’s something I’ll always bring with me. And you never know what’s gonna happen in the future.”
During the campaign, Ms Seoige received criticism over an ad campaign on cancer care in Galway.
In response to that criticism, today Ms Seoige said the ad was “100pc factual” as she added: “I’m glad it started the conversation. I had people at the doors, nurses, saying thank you for saying that.”
Ms Seoige, who is well known as a TV personality, also commented on the tag “celebrity candidate”.
“The celebrity thing is a tag you like to attach and it’s not a nice one, because it makes somebody else is without substance and I have plenty of substance.
“I have been taking stuff like this as I’ve entered media in 1996, I’m well used to labels, it’s something that happens to women all over society and women in politics even more.”
1.30pm – As we wait for count number seven, Fine Gael TD Hildegarde Naughton has arrived to the count centre for the first time this weekend.
Minister Naughton so far received 6,065 votes and is currently neck and neck with Independent candidate Noel Thomas (6,437) and just ahead of second Fine Gale candidate Seán Kyne (5,402).
Talking to the Irish Independent, Hildegarde Naughton said she is happy with the result so far.
She said: “Here in Galway West Fine Gael have done very well, I have increased my first preference vote and my percentage here of the vote of the last three elections. Myself and Seán Kyne performed very well, we were intending and hoping for two seats here in Galway West, we were the only party who could realistically achieve that, and we’re very happy with the Fine Gael vote when you look at our combined vote here in Galway West. It’s very good from that perspective.
She added she would have not changed anything in her running campaign.
“I worked very hard personally over the last few years. I went out on my own record, I now Seán did too. We are two very experienced candidates here for Galway West, we have both been councillors, TDs, we sat at the cabinet table and my belief is that Galway needs strong voices like myself and Seán to represent the area.
“Everybody does their best, you put out your best platform and we would be campaigned on our track record, we just have to sit and see now what the people of Galway West decide.”
She added transfer votes will be “critical” today both locally and nationally.
“Nationally I think we are doing very well, there are still seats in contention across the country, we have a lot of new candidates who are performing really well. I canvassed up and down the country with many of them throughout the campaign, they are very experienced, they are resonating very well with their electorate, but we just have to wait and see now, transfers are going to be critical down to the last few seats in all constituencies.”
1pm – Sixth count results have been announced. Nobody was elected. Pauline O'Reilly was eliminated and her votes will now be redistributed.
John Connolly 7354
Catherine Connolly 7170
Mike Cubbard 2419
Mairead Farrell 8582
Noel Grealish 7228
Seán Kyne 5402
Hildegarde Naughton 6065
Pauline O'Reilly 1918
Helen Ogbu 2106
Gráinne Seoige 2962
Eibhlín Seoighthe 2518
Noel Thomas 6437
12pm – The fifth count has been announced just before lunchtime today. Nobody was elected, Padraig Lenihan was eliminated and his votes will not be redistributed.
John Connolly 7230
Catherine Connolly 7034
Mike Cubbard 2310
Mairead Farrell 8445
Noel Grealish 6956
Seán Kyne 5351
Padraig Lenihan 1419
Hildegarde Naughton 6031
Pauline O'Reilly 1892
Helen Ogbu 2079
Gráinne Seoige 2941
Eibhlín Seoighthe 2493
Noel Thomas 6049
10.50am – The fourth count has been announced. Once again, nobody was elected. Maisie McMaster has now been eliminated and her votes will be redistributed at the next count.
John Connolly 7226
Catherine Connolly 6860
Mike Cubbard 2291
Mairead Farrell 8232
Noel Grealish 6951
Seán Kyne 5349
Padraig Lenihan 1407
Maisie McMaster 926
Hildegarde Naughton 6025
Pauline O'Reilly 1843
Helen Ogbu 1982
Gráinne Seoige 2937
Eibhlín Seoighthe 2177
Noel Thomas 6033
10.15am – The third count has been announced. AJ Cahill has been eliminated and his votes will now be redistributed.
AJ Cahill 631
John Connolly 7203
Catherine Connolly 6770
Mike Cubbard 2250
Mairead Farrell 8195
Patrick Feeney 52
Noel Grealish 6905
Seán Kyne 5338
Padraig Lenihan 1303
Doran McMahon 455
Maisie McMaster 916
Hildegarde Naughton 6015
Pauline O'Reilly 1840
Helen Ogbu 1977
Gráinne Seoige 2934
Eibhlín Seoighthe 2175
Noel Thomas 5815
9.40am – Less than an hour since kicking off, the second count has been announced: nobody was elected, Doran McMahon's votes will now be redistributed.
AJ Cahill 475
John Connolly 7195
Catherine Connolly 6752
Mike Cubbard 2223
Mairead 8169
Noel Grealish 6888
Seán Kyne 5335
Padraig Lenihan 1238
Doran McMahon 455
Maisie McMaster 907
Hildegarde Naughton 6014
Pauline O'Reilly 1839
Helen Ogbu 1976
Gráinne Seoige 2932
Eibhlín Seoighthe 2174
Noel Thomas 5703
9am – The second count has begun at Galway City's Lawn Tennis Club. After the first count arrived late last night, now Patrick Feeney’s votes will be redistributed.
I have more snacks as this is set to be a long day, the room is already filled with journalists and TD Catherine Connolly has already been spotted.
Sinn Féin Mairead Farrell topped the poll in Galway West last night with 8,164 votes and she is followed by John Connolly (7,192), Noel Grealish (6,887), Catherine Connolly (6,747), Hildegarde Naughton (6,011), Noel Thomas (5,700), and Seán Kyne (5,335).
While Fianna Fáil celebrity candidate Gráinne Seoige’s hopes for her first Dáil seat have been axed at the first count.
11.30pm – After about 14 hours since the opening of the boxes, the first count has finally been announced. The quota is 10,047 and as nobody was elected, Patrick Feeney’s votes will now be redistributed.
That’s it for tonight from the Galway's Lawn Tennis Club. The count will resume tomorrow morning at 9am.
AJ Cahil 469
John Connolly 7192
Catherine Connolly 6747
Mike Cubbard 2219
Mairead Farrell 8164
Patrick Feeney 52
Noel Grealish 6887
Seán Kyne 5335
Padraig Lenihan 1233
Doran McMahon 450
Maisie McMaster 905
Hildegarde Naughton 6011
Pauline O'Reilly 1839
Helen Ogbu 1973
Gráinne Seoige 2929
Eibhlín Seoighthe 2172
Noel Thomas 5700
10pm – I’m afraid there hasn’t been any update since the late afternoon as Galway West is still waiting for the first count to be announced.
6.30pm – The first count is expected to be announced soon and I’m already halfway through my pack of biscuits.
In the meantime, Fianna Fáil John Connolly has arrived at the count centre.
He said: “Tallies are looking positive but it should be noted that they are just tallies and there are many twists and turns that may happen in a count like this with elimination and transfer of votes, but at the moment I’m in a reasonably positive position based on the tallies. I hope there would be a transfer coming from my running mate, that would assist to keep my ahead of those who come behind me.
“I feel quite positive about it, I just hope it goes how it looks at the moment.”
4pm – As we are waiting for the first count to be announced, independent TD Catherine Connolly said she is delighted with the tallies’ results. “I’m delighted about the feedback and the feedback on the doors, I don’t know which seat I’ll take but it looks positive and I’m delighted with that.
"I’ve always regarded as a privilege to be a TD in the Dáil. That sense of being a privilege has kept me going.
“I don’t like politics, I’ve never liked it, but it’s a privilege and I think I have an obligation to speak out and put forward an alternative vision to the one put forward by the government for the last number of years.”
2.10pm – The tallies have spoken!
96pc of the boxes have been tallied and results show Sinn Féin Mairéad Farrell is leading at 13pc.
She is followed by Fianna Fáil John Connolly (12pc), independent Catherine Connolly (11pc), independent Noel Grealish (12pc), Fine Gael Hildegarde Naughton (10pc), Independent Ireland Noel Thomas (10pc) and Fine Gael Seán Kyne (9pc).
They are then followed by Fianna Fáil Gráinne Seoige (5pc), Social Democrats Eibhlín Seoighthe (4pc), independent Mike Cubbard (3pc), Labour Party Helen Ogbu (3pc), Green Party Pauline O’Reilly (3pc), Aontú Pádraig Lenihan (2pc), Irish Freedom Party Doran McMahon (1pc), People Before Profit-Solidarity Maisie McMaster (1pc), independent Patrick Feeney (0pc).
12.35pm – Fine Gael Senator Seán Kyne has arrived at the Galway West count centre and told the Irish Independent he is happy with the results so far.
"We only have 66pc of the boxes tallied so far and there’s some more to come in and other parties might have the tally sheets. So we don’t know, but there’s definitely one Fine Gael seat.
Talking about his campaign, he added: “I’m relatively happy, considering that I have a running mate in my own parish who did very well .
“I was happy with the response, I was happy with the groundcover, the weather played against us in the end but it played against everyone so I’m quite happy.”
In the meantime, other familiar faces have been spotted at the count centre as Galway City and County councillors came to support their party’s candidates.
Among them, Fianna Fáil Galway City Councillor Alan Cheevers said he is cautiously optimistic: "We’re happy with what the tallies are showing so far.
“I think that what we’re seeing here and the trend that we’re seeing here today probably reflects on the exit polls so far. We’re hopeful for both our candidates, let’s see what happens at the end of the day.”
12.25pm – 63pc of the boxes have bene opened and ‘tallied’.
According to tallies, Fine Gael is now at 19pc followed by Fianna Fáil (17pc) and Sinn Féin (13pc).
In particular, Fianna Fáil's John Connolly is at 12pc, while Gráinne Seoige is still at 5pc; Seán Kyne is at 10pc and Hildegarde Naughton is at 9pc.
Independent candidates are still going strong with Catherine Connolly at 12pc and Noel Grealish at 10pc. Also, Independent Ireland’s Noel Thomas is currently at 11pc.
11.35am – 34pc of the boxes have been opened in Galway West and tallies revealed independent candidates are still leading the way.
Catherine Connolly is at 12pc and the four independent candidates together are now at 43pc.
Fine Gael is now at 20pc followed by Fianna Fáil (18pc) and Sinn Féin (12pc).
Fianna Fáil's John Connolly (13pc) is still ahead of Gráinne Seoige (5pc); while Senator Seán Kyne (11pc) is ahead of Hildegarde Naughton (9pc).
11.15am – Social Democrats' Eibhlín Seoighthe is the first candidate through the Galway West count centre's doors today.
Talking with the Irish Independent, she said: “It’s early, but it’s looking interesting, the transfers are looking interesting. They are a bit more scattered, usually they are a bit more predictable, but they seem to be a bit all over the place. It’s still up in the air for now.
She added she is proud of her team and the campaign they have run: “My team were absolutely amazing, we did the best that we could. If I had had more time or if I could divided myself into seven I would have tried to hit as many doors as possible, but the time just wasn’t there.
“We did ourselves proud. It was a great first run at the general I’d say.”
10.30am – We’re well underway here at Galway City's Lawn Tennis Club, where the boxes for Galway West were opened at 9am.
Sinn Féin, Fianna Fáil and Fine Gael are neck and neck in Galway West according to early tallies, but independent candidate Catherine Connolly is currently leading the way.
Tallies show independent candidate Catherine Connolly is leading with 801 votes, making the independent candidates the 45pc of the total so far.
She is followed by Sinn Féin (16pc), Fianna Fáil (15pc) and Fine Gael (15pc).
According to tallies, Fianna Fáil candidate John Connolly has so far received 707 votes, while Gráinne Seoige has only received 140.
Independent candidate Patrick Feeney could be the first casualty of the day as he only received 6 votes so far.
